page.title: 01ALFOLD & UPPER IFOLD-A VIEW
page.content: The original Domesday Book bears no mention to Alfold. It was, however, recorded in a register kept by the Bishop of Winchester in 1240. The village is surrounded on all sides by coppice and woodlands of deciduous trees and conifers. The soil is typical of the Weald, being heavy clay where little grows well except oak trees, grass and some wheat. The farmers in the area utilize their land for intensively managed grassland used for sheep, horses, and cattle. A great deal of the woodland in the north of the area is managed by the Forestry Commission who keep a check and control on the great numbers of deer who roam freely. There is no heavy industry. We are served by a village shop and post office, two public houses, a 12th century church, a chapel and a pottery.
